chapter.title: Introduction to the &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server
chapter.para: The &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server is an open source, software based implementation of the VoIP network element responsible for media handling. It supports IP and TDM interfaces, and can act as both a Media Server and as a Media Gateway. It provides support for both distributed and centralized services, including circuit switch voice/video, announcements and tones.

In the modern VoIP world, providers offer highly customized services that combine media such as audio, video and IM. These services require dedicated and customized media processing capabilities. To achieve this, the VoIP network separates the media processing functions into a dedicated node which is responsible for media processing only, while all the intelligence is executed by the separate call controller. The node processing the media streams is called a Media Server.
The media handling node must also be able to bridge the gap between traditional legacy systems and modern VoIP networks. This node is typically called a Media Gateway.

The &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server can operate with the &THIS.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Application Server. However, the Media Server comes with a telco standard MGCP interface, which allows you to use another call controller if desired.

The &THIS.PLATFORM; Media Server is also equipped with an implementation of the media control API compliant to JSR-309 specifications, which allows you to use the Media Server with the &THIS.PLATFORM; SIP Servlet Container.

The Media Server includes an embedded signaling gateway function which supports the complete set of TDM and IP signaling protocols. It supports TDM access variants like ETSI ISUP, PRI, as well as supporting signaling backhaul over IP with M3UA and SUA options.

The Media Server is implemented using the JBoss Microcontainer kernel, which allows you to archive maximum flexibility. It gives you the ability to adopt the Media Server for task specific actions, and/or extend the functions of the Media Server by installing additional media processing components.
